body.title: Agencies to Watch 2025 part 1: featuring AMV BBDO, Hearts and Science and Code and Theory
body.description: From up-and-coming startups to adland’s biggest players, this is our celebration of the agencies everyone should be keeping ...
body.article_content:
Be they the industry’s biggest players or the growing cast of upstarts seeking to steal their glory, 2025 promises to be a transformative year for agencies.

So, to coincide with our Predictions event on thedrum.com, each day this week we are spotlighting agencies that we believe are poised to make a major impact through their work and activities in the months ahead.

The featured agencies, which we are revealing in a series of articles published each day this week, hail from all corners of the world and represent a diverse range of specialisms. Some are well-established networks, others up-and-coming indies. But what they all have in common is that they have earned The Drum Recommends status based on their achievements in 2024.

So delve in now as we hear from our first 10 Agencies to Watch about how they are planning to tackle what promises to be one of the most intriguing and potentially disruptive years the marcomms business has ever seen.

One of the key players in the Stagwell stable, the New York-based ‘technology-first creative agency’ is positioning itself at the forefront of the marketing AI race.

Code and Theory

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Dan Gardner, co-founder: AI transformation is CX transformation. CX is about to go to a new level as AI will allow a brand to simulate real-time, human-like interactions. Most people see this as chatbots, but it’s more than that. The old constructs of the internet will be reinvented in a meaningful way that offers value to consumers by not only delivering information but also communicating with them on an emotional level. This is where the genuine innovation opportunity lies: combining technology and creativity for superior customer experiences.

CMOs, CIOs and CTOs will finally sit at the same table, not because they want to, but because they have to. AI, data, and customer experience are crashing into each other so violently that no one department can own the process any more. The only way forward is collaboration, and the stakes are too high to ignore. Companies that fail to unite these roles will see competitors blow past them with speed and agility.

Publishers will take the lead with technology. Building a sustainable future for publishers involves focusing on brands as a differentiator, regaining control over distribution (and data) and integrating AI to amplify human ingenuity. This will allow publishers to build genuine ecosystems of trust and deliver the kind of storytelling experience that will resonate, ensuring the industry’s place as a cornerstone of informed societies.”

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Gardner: Building AI accelerators. We made ourselves ‘Client Zero’ with AI – because how can clients trust us to transform their businesses if we haven’t mastered it ourselves? We’re deploying 19 AI platforms (so far) – everything from OpenAI (also a client) to Midjourney and Adobe Firefly (another client).

Expanding our network in terms of skillset and scale. Stagwell strategically decided to align all of its digital transformation agencies under the Code and Theory Network to deliver unparalleled creative and technology capabilities at scale. Together, we’re positioned to deliver comprehensive value for clients from concept to continuity, serving as strategic partners in AI-driven transformation. Last month we added to the network and to our global aspirations by acquiring Create. Group, the leading digital agency based in the UAE. Expect to see our network only grow stronger in the coming months.

Focusing on verticalization. We’re going big on verticalization in 2025. This has a dual effect: it gives our clients confidence knowing their assigned team has deep industry expertise, and it imbues team members with an opportunity to develop a distinct skill set.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Gardner: NBC ‘Powering the future of data journalism’: With trust in media at an all-time low, NBC partnered with Code and Theory to reimagine its election coverage Big Board, ensuring precision and credibility throughout the most consequential election in a generation (and beyond).

NFL ‘No Flags, Just Wins’: The NFL dominates American sports – it accounted for 93 of the 100 most-watched TV broadcasts in all of 2023. But even as the nation’s most-watched sport, the NFL needed to modernize its app to bring the game closer to its die-hard fan base and new fans alike. So the NFL called an audible and called in Code and Theory to transform its app into more than just a game-day companion, but an experience that fuels the rhythm of the game – every play, day and week, on- and off-season.

Yeti ‘Map The Gaps’: Google has mapped 98% of the world, 100 countries and 10m miles of concrete roads. But naturally, wilderness enthusiasts prefer the paths less paved. For Yeti, this posed an opportunity to take the Hopper M20 (our most versatile cooler yet), map hidden trails across the globe and make the outdoors more accessible to everyone. We built, designed and launched Map The Gaps – A Yeti campaign to take Google Street View way off the street, showing the world where the Hopper was built to go and inspiring Street View users around the world to explore the paths less paved.

The 600-strong agency network was acquired by Accenture Song in April 2024 and has continued to go from strength to strength, as recognized in being named Agency of the Year (250+ staff) at The Drum Awards for Agency Business.

Unlimited

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Chris Mellish, group chief executive officer: In 2025, the industry will be shaped by rapid technological advancements, but without a deep understanding of people and channels, tech risks becoming noise. While AI is top of mind, it must be used carefully – not as a lazy answer to every question, but as a tool to drive efficiencies, deliver better insights, and ultimately create more impactful work for brands.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Mellish: This year is going to be very busy for all the right reasons! Last year, TMW alone won 24 pitches, totaling £7.9m in new revenue, including Suzuki, Oak Furnitureland, People’s Postcode Lottery and Rail Delivery Group. We have a bit of a hot streak going on in the new business front across all our brands – our research agency, Walnut Unlimited, B2B communications and content marketing agency, Nelson Bostock and healthcare comms agency, Health Unlimited. We are now the go-to CRM agency of record for McDonald’s – our first with Accenture Song. This is just the beginning of what’s to come.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Mellish: Lots of work to be proud of. From our integrated creative agency TMW’s work for Suzuki Swift ‘The Best Kept Secret on the Road’ defying category norms against increasingly formulaic car ads, to our Pride in London work launching last year’s festival with a visual style as daring, fearless and authentic as the community themselves.

Want to go deeper? Ask The Drum

Nobody knows Kraft Heinz better than its in-house agency, whose string of hit-making work cleverly leveraging the company’s brand equity shows no sign of stopping.

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Playing it safe isn’t an option any more. This year, it’s all about brands making moves that people can’t stop talking about. ‘Culture Sparks’ are the way forward – those unexpected moments that break through the noise and leave an impact.

Brands are also bringing creativity closer to home. The shift to incorporating an in-house model is real, and it’s not just about speed – it’s about being in sync. When creative teams live the brand’s ambition every day, the work becomes sharper, more agile, and more authentic.

Relevance is the ultimate flex in 2025. It’s not about chasing trends but creating them.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Our growth is proof that bringing together the power of creativity with direct connection to brand teams and strategy works at The Kitchen North America. In just three years, we’ve gone from four to 19 brands and 35 to 135+ powerhouse creatives across two offices. We now work on 70% of the media plan for 90% of the brands, crafting full 360 campaigns, social-first content and cultural moments that hit different. As the creative agency of record for select brands, we don’t just answer briefs – we create them. This isn’t just growth; it’s impact, built on trust and bold ideas that keep Kraft Heinz ahead of the curve.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

We brought nostalgia back with the Napoleon Dynamite x Ore-Ida campaign, proving that tater-tot-protecting pants do exist. The Oscar Mayer’s Bologna Song became a literal form of payment, and when a viral moment such as Dua Lipa’s Pickle x Diet Coke popped off, we didn’t just watch – it sparked an idea for Claussen to launch ‘Just the Brine’ within days.

Now entering its fifth year, Fight or Flight is soaring thanks to its highly creative campaigns for B2B brands. The London-based outfit was the third-placed Independent Agency of the Year at The Drum Awards Grand Finale 2024.

Flight or Fight

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

David Woodward, co-founder: As the influence of brand inside B2B organizations rises, one thing we’re seeing is closer alignment between the brand and communications teams. Increasingly, B2B brand campaigns are being driven by earned tactics, and vice versa, comms teams are more frequently being tasked with promoting and explaining brand messages. We’re still seeing more traditional uses of B2B comms (for example, to support product), but in particular, this ‘culture swap’ of brand and comms is leading to better, more noticeable, more memorable and more emotively arresting work.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Woodward: We see 2025 as a continuation of our aggressive expansion into new markets and new opportunities. In 2024, alongside significant expansion in the UK, Fight or Flight achieved almost 100% growth in North America, driven partly by brand-level engagements for AI companies in sectors such as life sciences and HR. We expect the fast rate to continue as we further diversify our sector offerings into fintech and ESG.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Woodward: We’re particularly proud of our work for St John Ambulance, which wanted to encourage more people and workplaces to take its life-saving CPR training. Our research found that a third of men were too embarrassed to give a woman CPR, with potentially life-threatening consequences.

We created the world’s first life-saving bra – The CPR Bra – which included simple visual prompts on how to perform CPR on a woman. We then persuaded celebrities to wear the bra and help close the CPR gender gap. Our story went pretty much everywhere, including a 13-minute live slot on BBC Breakfast, turning ER into PR.

Our campaign for DrDoctor focused on ‘the DNA problem.’ DNAs (Did Not Attends) are patients who miss their hospital appointments. In the UK, there are 7 million DNAs every year and they cause huge operational issues for an already stretched NHS. To help Hospital Trusts understand why DNAs happen, we created DoNnA, the world’s first AI patient, trained on data taken from the largest-ever survey of DNA patients.

Advertisement

Helmed by the bullish Dimi Albers, the Amsterdam-headquartered agency has expanded into a global powerhouse with a presence in 30 offices across Europe, North America and Latin America.

Dept

Dimi Albers, global CEO: What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

In 2025, we’ll finally see AI move from an efficiency and cost-cutting tool to a force to reimagine how businesses operate, make decisions, and interact with consumers. As AI transformation takes center stage – and swift, strategic, and solutions-oriented applications of AI become a priority – the organizations that enable their people to transform with AI will distinguish themselves in an emerging sea of sameness.

Albers: What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Rebels with a B Corp cause: we are purpose-driven and invested, committed to building lasting client relationships and positively impacting culture, brands, and the world. We’re the first global agency to be B-Corp certified, and we’re currently undergoing recertification – a first in the industry. This means we’re building the plane as we fly it. While the agency world has been helping other brands sell sustainability (sometimes greenwash) for ages, it’s only been in the past few years that the industry has started to look inward and think about sustainability, ethics, and inclusion practices within our industry. Being a part of the B Corp Community helps us do that – and especially at our size, has helped us build the muscles around how to do that early.

Albers: What work were you most proud of in 2024?

For Just Eat Takeaway, a cross-discipline team of 35 creatives, technologists and producers brought fans of Squid Games together on a multisensory campaign spanning above-the-line, experiential, influencers and an AI-powered game.

For Cosnova, we built Kenna, an AI-enabled virtual assistant that can help customers explore new products and trends. Kenna is available across multiple channels including social, events, and POS.

In partnership with Coca-Cola, we created ‘Neon Nights,’ an AI-powered short story about a boy named Max. Using 12 generative tools and with over 600 hours of production, the film was submitted to Runway’s AI Film Festival.

Advertisement

Propelled by recently secured private equity investment, the ambitious UK-based social media and influencer agency is now targeting the US market.

Coolr

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Adam Clyne, chief executive officer: Predictions for 2025? From a social media agency owner? Really?! We’re only three weeks into the year, and already we’ve seen Meta replace fact-checking with community notes, a TikTok ban that lasted all of 12 hours, and Instagram switching up the grid layout… yet again. And that’s before we even consider the broader macroeconomic and political shifts – from the Middle East and Ukraine to a new president in the US, and here at home, a government grappling with economic challenges.

Let’s be honest: predicting trends when everything feels in constant flux is no easy task. But if I had to point to one key trend, it’s this: the marketing community will need to embrace the chaos! We’ll need to get comfortable operating in an environment of constant change, navigating uncertainty, and staying agile. Plans will evolve, and both agencies and clients will need to collaborate more closely than ever to adapt to external forces.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Clyne: 2024 was a phenomenal year for Coolr. The agency grew by almost 75% and towards the end of the year we secured investment from Growth Capital Partners, a leading private equity firm, to help scale Coolr to the next level.

We’ve made significant investments in people and technology to strengthen our strategic capabilities – from insights and planning to cutting-edge measurement. As we approach a headcount of 150 full-time employees in the UK, we’re focused on creating a robust operational structure to support our growth.

The big milestone for 2025? Expanding Coolr into the US. We’re actively building a comprehensive plan to take our proposition across the Atlantic. It’s an exciting step, and we’re determined to make Coolr a major player in the US market.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Clyne: 2024 was filled with creative highlights that we’re incredibly proud of. We teamed up with Martine McCutcheon and Lidl to put a fresh spin on Gina G’s classic song, creating ‘Oh, Ah, Just a Lidl Bit!’ – a campaign that set social media alight and delivered a standout moment for supermarkets.

For Deliveroo, we championed local restaurants with the ‘Local’ campaign, working alongside Top Jaw and nano influencers to celebrate independent food businesses across the UK.

And with Bupa, we sparked vital conversations about mental health, particularly focusing on the 58% of men who struggle to open up about these issues. It was work that truly mattered, and we were proud to play a role in starting those important discussions.

The Omnicom media agency has developed an uncanny knack for working on some of the most talked-about campaigns of recent times, including the acclaimed Barbie movie media blitz and Jaguar’s hotly debated ‘Copy Nothing’ makeover rollout.

Hearts and Science

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Garrett O’Reilly, chief executive officer: AI will likely feature heavily as it’s already a focal point for lots of people and its transformational impact will continue into 2025. One particular area I think it will start to tangibly impact will be AI-driven search. The growing prevalence and usage of AI assistants on devices will grow and will have profound disruptive effects on consumer behavior and fundamentally change how people find answers to all sorts of questions. Brands will need to optimize sales and their purchase funnels in accordance with that and we’ll have to adapt our services to help clients adjust to (and win in) this new reality.

If the first few weeks of 2025 are indicative of what’s to come, there will also be uncertainty in policies and platform governance. In the face of this, our industry must remain focussed on responsible marketing – even if this centers on self-control and self-governance over third-party regulation. This means it’s on us, as an industry, to foreground all aspects of responsible marketing: diversity, equity, inclusion, environmental sustainability, data protection and ethical investment practices.

That said, I’m optimistic that this shifting landscape will drive greater media diversification as we find new ways to deliver value for clients. Agencies will play a critical role in guiding brands toward more innovative solutions, new partnerships and experimentation.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

O’Reilly: We’re particularly excited to continue leveraging our sponsorship of the Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, ensuring its huge bank of empirical evidence, research and insights benefit both our agency and our clients. This will include evolving our industry-leading Category Entry Points tool, which is driving business growth for an increasing range of clients.

Our Access All Agency initiative will return for a second year – bigger and better. The program, launched as an educational initiative for rising stars among our media owner partners, aims to deepen their understanding of how agencies operate and thus drive greater collaboration.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

O’Reilly: 2024 was our most successful year to date in terms of industry awards, and that speaks volumes. But what’s particularly pleasing was lots of our work became part of wider culture and in doing so generated disproportionate visibility for our clients’ brands.

A big focus for us was delivering the biggest account transition in the UK for over a decade as we onboarded Allwyn. While this was a great success in operational terms, we’re immensely proud of the work we’ve already delivered for them this year. The highlight of 2024 for me has to be supporting Team GB and ParalympicsGB. Our work drove a double-digit rise in consideration for the brand and every ticket sold contributed to the UK’s haul of 189 medals.

It was also great to be part of one of the most talked about campaigns of the year. Our work with Jaguar on its Copy Nothing campaign earned the title of YouGov’s ‘most improved brand’ in December, outperforming all the Christmas ads…. And there’s still the actual car to come.

The female-led agency has the US in its sights having made its mark with eye-catching brand experiences for the likes of McDonald’s, Netflix and Volvo in its UK home market.

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Louisa O’Connor, managing director: Collective experiences will define 2025 – people value shared emotions and memories, and brands are seeing the impact this has on their resonance. We’re also seeing the rise of the common influencer, which is reshaping marketing strategies; consumers are becoming the heroes versus paid creators, driven by the demand for authenticity. I think we’ll also see nostalgia remain a key trend, with the focus shifting from retro aesthetics to simplification and a need to go back to basics as the tech world can feel overwhelming.

In experiential marketing, we see a lot of tech used for tech’s sake. However, brands are moving away from that to focus on the human aspect, tapping into the niche needs of the individual instead of the masses. Consumers crave simplicity and look for brands to alleviate their pain points, which is now influencing how we design experiences. It’s less about what an activation will look like on a camera and more about the emotion that an experience can create.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

O’Connor: This will be our fourth year of trading, and as we expand, we have two main priorities. Firstly, we are focused on growing our content and broadcast team. Working with many social-first brands, we want to push our live streaming, content creation, scriptwriting and show curation capabilities. Secondly, the US is calling. Having activated there a few times already, we believe now is the time to solidify our presence and serve our existing US clients more holistically. Some of the most exciting events in the world are hosted there, so it’s a no-brainer for us to expand our offering and bring our Seen Presents way to the US market.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

O’Connor: It was our second year delivering Netflix’s presence at Cannes Lions, where we brought seven different titles to life in unique and participatory ways. Not only does this project showcase our team’s creativity, but it also blends our strategy, content and production capabilities to deliver something truly spectacular. It’s a huge logistics and production challenge: building six floors above the Croisette, with crane-only access, while the team is completely exposed to the elements.

We ended 2024 preparing for Live Fest – one of the biggest events in TikTok’s calendar – consisting of four live events in six days and logistics for 600 creators from around the world. From hospitality, activations, complex live streaming, red carpet logistics, RFID systems and talent sourcing and booking – it truly touched every area of our business. It was a mammoth effort and a career highlight for us all.

Suggested newsletters for you Daily Briefing Catch up on the most important stories of the day, curated by our editorial team. Weekly Marketing Stay up to date with a curated digest of the most important marketing stories and expert insights from our global team. The Drum Insider Learn how to pitch to our editors and get published on The Drum.

The serial Ad of the Day and The Drum Awards winner shows no sign of slowing down on its convention-defying advertising for the likes of Bodyform and Curry’s.

AMV BBDO

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Sam Williams, head of strategy: Bringing a human face to big data: “Data driven creative” is a phrase that’s dominated the industry for the last decade, but the risk is hyper-targeting without the humanity. It’s time to show that the power of emotion can be applied just as effectively in performance media as in storytelling formats. At AMV we’ve built a proprietary data tool called Kaleidoscope, which allows us to track consumer emotions at scale by time, day of the week and by geography – giving us an emotional lens which can be overlaid onto demographic data.

Learn from AI, then break the rules: We see AI is a powerful way of quickly getting to creative ground zero. But we have to remember that its output is limited by convention and the data available to it – this grounds it in uniformity, not bravery. AI can accelerate the beginning of the creative process by showing us the expected, then giving us the confidence to break the rules and do something stand out. Afterall, no AI would have told us the creative way to launch new Sheba Gravy Pouches was by pitting “catfluencers” against each other in the ultimate Gravy Race.

Beyond inclusivity to accessibility: It’s time to stop seeing accessibility as a creative hindrance and see it as a creative tool we can use to make the experience richer for all. It’s no longer enough to make your cast and production crew inclusive, your output must be accessible too. It’s a belief we’ve pushed on our Curry’s C4 diversity win and an ethos we’re now rolling out across the agency briefing and production process.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Xavier Rees, group CEO: Last year, we rediscovered our best selves – a powerhouse of strategy and creativity. We were back in the room for some of the industry’s most competitive pitches, securing four major account wins in the last four months of 2024 alone, including Mercedes F1 Team, E.ON Next and Philips Personal Care. And we continued to craft impactful and effective work that real people love for clients, including Guinness’ largest-ever global campaign, more taboo-breaking campaigns for Bodyform, and bold work for Currys, which is really impacting on sales.

If last year was about setting the stage for success, 2025 is about delivering on that promise. In January, we strengthened our Executive Leadership Team with Jo Arden joining as group chief strategy officer and Jemima Monies as group chief growth officer. The roles further consolidate our focus on driving business transformation and creative excellence across AMV BBDO and Redwood BBDO. Jo and Jemima will work alongside the Leadership Teams of both agencies, including AMV BBDO joint chief creative officers Nick and Nadia. We have new, exciting campaigns coming out for much-loved brands Whiskas, Decathlon, Sheba and Maltesers, and we’re gearing up to launch our Channel 4 Diversity in Advertising Awards-winning work for Currys, in May.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Nadja Lossgott, chief creative officer: Bodyform ‘Never Just a Period’: the work sees Bodyform widening the conversation around menstruation with another viral punch. Directed by the brilliant Lucy Forbes, “Never Just a Period” humorously brings to life the gap between what girls are taught to expect and the reality of menstrual experiences, and how absurd it is to have been given so little knowledge about their own bodies.

Currys ‘Beyond Techspectations – IRL’: The Drum Ad Of The Day, Currys ‘Beyond Techspectations’ series ventures into mockumentary territory in AMV BBDO’s film “Amazing Us (IRL)”, showing online shoppers venturing into a real-life Currys store and discovering the joy of shopping in person – even if they struggle to give up some of their digital habits, such as swiping right and trying to magnify images.

Sheba ‘Gravy Race’: AMV BBDO has enlisted eight celebrity felines with a combined 55 million TikTok and Instagram followers to compete in a bracket-style tournament where they raced each other to lick up Sheba’s new Gravy Indulgence cat food. By breaking with the clichés of pet food advertising, the Gravy Race delivered an entertaining piece of content that cut through the sea of sameness.

Mercedes F1 ‘Every Dream Needs a Team’: As the 2024 F1 season came to an end at the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on December 8, we helped the Mercedes-AMG Petronas F1 Team to pay tribute to Lewis Hamilton in a heartfelt global campaign.

RSPCA ‘For Every Kind’: The RSPCA unveile its major new brand positioning with AMV BBDO’s film ‘For Every Kind,’ a rallying cry for every kind of person to be kind in every possible way to every kind of animal.

Founded in 1985, the stalwart agency was snapped up by Havas in early 2024 to spearhead its B2B marketing efforts and looks well-placed to leverage its newfound scale.

What trends will shape the industry in 2025?

Andrea Glenn, CEO: AI... just kidding. Clients are starting to realize they have a wealth of B2B opportunity in their businesses already, but organizational silos are holding them back from realizing their full B2B potential. Marketing and sales don’t nor can work in siloes, nor customer and product. As such, clients look for more full-service offerings from agencies that both bind creative and media together and have the scale to do it. And they don’t want CRM, ABM, web and so forth operating separately with a single partner each. Instead, they are on the hunt for consultative partners who can bring these functions together to deliver customer lifetime value. We’re excited to see this unleash further opportunity in B2B, a space that remains ripe for growth for many businesses and agencies alike.

What does the agency have planned for 2025?

Glenn: We have some exciting plans this year, which would not have been possible without the scale Havas Media Network and Havas Group can offer. When looking at partners who could help us achieve our strategic objectives, global expansion – including in the markets we already operate – was key and this year, we are looking to increase our foothold in Ireland and the US particularly, where we will partner with Havas Media Network North America to build a full-service B2B offering to work with B2B and B2C brands. We’re now in a position to provide a full-service offering to clients that straddle both B2B and B2C in North America. Our chief strategy officer will be relocating to New York to lead our North American expansion. In this context, our decision to be acquired by Havas Media Network UK last year and our shared pursuit of customer-centricity has been a brilliant mutual culture fit.

What work were you most proud of in 2024?

Glenn: GE Vernova ‘How to Launch an ABM Campaign in Five Days’: GE Vernova’s marketing team needed to grow its sales pipeline by 4x for its new power orchestration solution – all within H1. To achieve this audacious goal, we held a kaizen (or continuous improvement) session. This involved taking our client’s people out of their daily responsibilities and bringing them together around a single-minded purpose. In just five days, we identified priority audiences, began mapping accounts, created a value proposition, key messaging, and content strategy, developed a sales process, and launched 1-to-1 and 1-to-few ABM programs. This strategy garnered real results, including a x2 increase in pipeline within 30 days of the kaizen.

body.title: Should Gen Z be cancelled for their ‘inappropriate’ office wear?
body.description: Young employees are dressing as they want at their workplaces. Fashion trends like ‘office siren’ and ‘corpcore’ have gone viral on TikTok. However, some of these work outfits have landed them in a so ...
body.article_content:
Young employees are dressing as they want at their workplaces. Fashion trends like ‘office siren’ and ‘corpcore’ have gone viral on TikTok. However, some of these work outfits have landed them in a soup with their organisations read more

Young employees are getting in trouble at their workplaces for their outfits. Gen Z has adopted a more relaxed workplace attire, ditching business formals. They are expressing themselves through their dressing style.

But not everyone is happy with Gen Z workers chasing a more casual workplace outfit. Some young workers are even bearing the brunt for their fashion choices.

Let’s take a closer look.

Gen Z opt for casual office wear

Young workers are getting inspired by TikTok workwear influencers to decide how to dress at work.

Fashion trends like “office siren”, wearing tailored blazers and statement glasses paired with sensual makeup and tight skirts; “corpcore”, modernising the usual 9-to-5 attire with unique tailoring and quirky accessories; “corporate goth”, an all-black attire, are going viral in young corporate America, as per Fortune magazine.

Advertisement

According to a Gallup survey published in September 2023, about 41 per cent of American workers said they wear business-casual clothes to work, 31 per cent wear street clothes and 23 per cent wear uniforms. Only 3 per cent said they wear a suit regularly to work.

Young workers are getting inspired by TikTok workwear influencers to decide their work outfit. Representational Image/Pixabay

Many Gen Z brands have noticed this trend among young workers and have launched clothing catering to them. ASOS, Urban Outfitters, Boohoo, and Cider offer “office siren” look.

Aritzia has an office campaign ad on the “office siren” trend featuring a tight-fitting, off-the-shoulder dress, reported The Wall Street Journal.

Everlane and PrettyLittleThing also have a shopping tab for “corpore” clothes.

It is not just America, Gen Z and millennial employees in Singapore are also opting for more comfortable or casual outfits than formal suits, reported The Straits Times.

Why is this happening?

The shift towards casual business attire has been gradual as young workers navigate modern office dress codes. Many office traditions went for a toss during the Covid-19 pandemic.

As work from home became the norm, the boundaries of office attire were further pushed.

Speaking to The Straits Times, country manager Linda Teo of recruitment firm ManpowerGroup said, “During the pandemic, many employees had to work remotely for extended periods, leading to a shift towards a greater emphasis on comfort and practicality in daily attire.

Advertisement

“As employees return to the office, we’re seeing organisations adopt more relaxed dress codes to accommodate these new preferences.”

A survey of American workers by Clarify Capital last year found that 75 per cent of those surveyed believed that the workplace has become “less formal” in recent years.

They attributed the shift towards a less formal workplace to several reasons. As many as 66 per cent of respondents said casual dress was becoming more common, about 59 per cent reported changes in societal norms and values, and 54 per cent said it was due to the influence of younger generations on the workplace.

Advertisement

For Gen Z, their office attire is a way to reflect their individuality.

Teo from recruitment firm ManpowerGroup told The Straits Times that young workers have a “distinct” style sense that shows their individuality. “This generation tends to incorporate personal touches into their professional look, blending contemporary fashion trends with professional standards to express their unique style within the boundaries of acceptable workplace attire of their organisations.”

Gen Z gets flak for casual office wear

Some believe Gen Z is taking inspiration for office wear from the wrong places like TikTok. And they are facing the consequences for it.

A video shared by one Abby on TikTok last August said some Gen Z workers are landing in a soup at work because of their “inappropriate” attire.

“The reason that all of these kids are getting in trouble for the clothing that they’re wearing to the office is because they’re getting their inspiration from content creators, not from actual nine-to-five workers,” she said in the clip.

Advertisement

“There are so many fashion creators that are creating like ’nine to five working inspo’ that have never touched an office in their lives.”

A young employee took to TikTok to share how she got in trouble for her office wear. Kiera Bohan posted an “outfit of the day” (OOTD) video on the social media platform from her office in which she was seen wearing a white cropped sweater, green canvas pants, and chunky sneakers. She captioned the clip, “recorded this ootd at work and then got in trouble for having my [midriff] showing.” Bohan added, “now looking back my outfit was not cute enough to risk it #ootd #9to5.”

Advertisement

Experts told Fortune that crop tops, running sneakers and athletic clothes are a few common mistakes that employees make in their workwear outfits.

“Athleisure is probably the most common [Gen Z styling issue] that I see, because it’s turned into some people’s day-to-day wear. There’s a fine-line between athleisure and athletic wear,” Myka Meier, a modern etiquette coach, said to the magazine. “I have a law firm I work for and the workers are all in suits. They have sneakers on, but really nice leather sneakers, not athletic running shoes. That’s the difference.”

Some even question the hyper-sexual version of work outfits that trends like “office siren” promote.

Camille Bradbury, Director of HR Communication at Matchr.com, told Newsweek it was important to let employees express their individuality at work— with taste.

“Taste, meaning modesty and business professional attire,” she said. “This means avoiding showing too much skin at work, like low-cut shirts that expose lots of cleavage or chest hair, or short skirts. I think there’s a way to express our individuality without being sexual.”

Some say wearing professional clothes helps them distinguish between their personal and private lives.

Dress for the job you want, they say.

As Meier told Fortune, “The main advice I give Gen Z is that you have to dress for the brand and industry you’re working for. If you work for a trendy marketing firm in New York City, then you probably can wear leggings and have navy blue nail polish. But if you work for a corporate bank, then that doesn’t work.”

With inputs from agencies

body.title: Scientists discover two mountains taller than Everest hidden deep within Earth
body.description: Scientists have discovered massive structures deep inside Earth, beneath Africa and the Pacific Ocean. These structures are ...
body.article_content:
Earth's biggest hidden mountains revealed deep beneath Africa and the Pacific Ocean

Scientists find mysterious "islands" beneath Earth with unpredictable seismic behavior



Unusual seismic behaviour revealed Earth's deepest secrets

Also Read:

Scientists have discovered two enormous structures deep inside Earth whose sizes are forcing scientists to rethink the way they see the inside of their planet, at the boundary between Earth's core and the mantle, beneath Africa and the Pacific Ocean, these "islands" described as continent-sized regions whose temperatures are thousands of degrees higher than the average temperature of the surroundings. According to new research from Utrecht University, these structures are not only gigantic but also old, with origins at least half a billion years ago. The discovery raises new questions about the geological history of the planet and the forces shaping its interior, offering fresh insights into Earth's dynamic evolution.The world's largest mountains have been found deep inside Earth, according to a landmark paper published in the journal Nature today. These giants are some 100 times higher than Mount Everest, rising 1,000 kilometers, while Everest's peak is about 8.8 kilometers above the sea. Researchers estimate that these mountains are at least half a billion years old, dating back to the Earth's formation, over four billion years ago.Scientists say the mountains are at least 500 million years old and probably date back to Earth's origin. Surrounding the mountains is tectonic debris that comes from subduction, in which one tectonic plate is sunk beneath another. Seismic shockwaves have led scientists to reveal these giant land masses hidden in Earth's core and map its interior. The lead researcher, Dr. Arwen Deuss, does not know the origin of these mountains; it is a matter of whether they are transient structures or an old age mountain. This new discovery shook the understanding that existed within geology and further revealed the dynamics into the history of the Earth's interior.LLSVPs Large Low Seismic Velocity Provinces Large blobs of unknown, mysterious material lurking deep beneath our Earth's surface lie at the core-mantle boundary beneath Africa and the Pacific Ocean. Enormous "islands," they are found surrounded by a "graveyard" of cold sunken tectonic plates descended through the mantle via subduction. Seismic waves are slowed down as they travel through Earth's interior because of its very high temperatures in these regions.In a new study, researchers Arwen Deuss and Sujania Talavera-Soza approached things differently. Instead of measuring just the slowdown of seismic waves, they measured the waves' damping, or how much energy the waves lose as they travel. Contrary to their expectations, they found that the LLSVPs caused minimal damping, making seismic waves unusually loud, while the surrounding cold tectonic plate graveyard dampened the waves more, offering new insights into Earth's deep interior.The LLSVPs have remained enigmatic with deep, puzzling features located deep in Earth. Located near the boundary between Earth's core and its mantle, LLSVPs are hotter than surrounding tectonic plates. Analyzing seismic waves did something surprising; their energy dissipation or loss due to friction with Earth was lower compared to what has been considered usual, thereby causing the sound emitted to be surprisingly louder than other seismic events.Differently, the cold tectonic plate graveyard exhibited tremendous damping where the waves could be described to be softer. This was contrary to previous assumptions set forth that the upper mantle would dampen the waves. The scientists believe that the LLSVPs are much older and include bigger grain minerals that take less energy absorbed, meaning that explains their unusual seismic response.

body.title: Scientists finally solve the mystery of a strange whitish-grey patch spotted in the northern lights
body.description: A new discovery has unveiled the origin of a strange whitish-grey patch seen with the northern lights. This phenomenon, now ...
body.article_content:
Images of the aurora borealis displaying the structured continuum emission. (Image: Courtesy Faculty of Science research team)

A new discovery has unveiled the origin of a strange whitish-grey patch seen with the northern lights. This phenomenon, now termed a "structured continuum emission," offers fresh insight into the aurora borealis’ complexities.

Aurora's Hidden Companion

The unusual pale patch often appears alongside dynamic auroras. Dr Emma Spanswick, a physics professor at the University of Calgary, led the study. “This patch is intricately linked with the aurora,” she explained. Researchers have now confirmed it is a heat source, making the aurora even more complex.

Story continues below Advertisement Remove Ad

While previously noted in scientific records, its nature remained a mystery. Published in Nature Communications, the study marks the first clear explanation.

Role of Advanced Camera Technology

The discovery relied on cutting-edge camera sensors capturing true-colour images. Dr Spanswick highlighted how advancements in digital photography have benefited science. “Modern sensors, now commercially available, help identify such celestial phenomena,” she said.

The team also drew connections to STEVE, another sky phenomenon. Unlike STEVE’s separate mauve ribbon, this patch blends into auroras.

Student Involvement Sparks Future Research

Three University of Calgary students contributed significantly to this study. Undergraduate Josh Houghton played a key role in data analysis. “It was an incredible learning experience,” he said. Houghton will continue this research as part of his honours thesis and future master’s degree.

This finding highlights how collaboration and technology advance our understanding of cosmic mysteries.

body.title: When does daylight saving time start? Here's why President Trump wants to get rid of it
body.description: As January draws to an end, Texas can look forward to daylight saving time as an indication of spring. Here's why President ...
body.article_content:
As January draws to a close, the end of winter is in sight. As of last Friday, we've officially made it out of the 10 darkest weeks of the year. While the days grow longer, daylight saving time is just around the corner.

When does daylight saving time start in 2025?

Daylight saving time is set to begin on Sunday, March 9, 2025. In the early hours, time will jump forward by one hour from 2 a.m. to 3 a.m. This marks the shift to local Daylight Saving Time (DST).

Many devices, such as phones and computers, will automatically change to DST, but non-smart devices, such as microwaves and some car radios, as well as any clock with hands, will likely need to be changed manually.

What does daylight saving time mean?

The end of daylight saving time means there will be more light in the morning and it will get dark earlier in the evening. Sunrise and sunset will be about one hour earlier on Sunday, Nov. 3, than they were on Saturday, Nov. 2.

For most Americans, except those in Arizona, Hawaii, and a handful of other places, the end of daylight saving time means an extra hour of sleep on Nov. 5. It also helps the country accommodate for more daylight in the mornings in preparation for winter.

How did daylight saving time start?

Daylight saving time (DST) claims a variety of other names: daylight savings time, daylight time, summer time (not to be confused with summertime). It refers to the practice of setting clocks forward by one hour during the warmer months of the year and then setting them back one hour in the fall.

One way to remember the pattern: "spring forward, fall back."

The idea dates back to World War I, although some credit Benjamin Franklin for daylight saving time due to a satirical letter he wrote in 1784 stating: "Every morning, as soon as the sun rises, let all the bells in every church be set ringing: and if that is not sufficient, let cannon be fired in every street to wake the sluggards effectually."

To maximize resources for the war, Germany and Austria implemented the first daylight saving time in 1916. The U.S. did the same in 1918. An outdated idea, some argue.

The general idea of daylight saving time is to maximize the use of natural daylight, according to the Almanac. This always occurs around the summer months. As the earth moves around the sun and is tilted on its axis, certain parts of the world experience longer days during certain months. For those in the northern hemisphere, like the U.S., these longer days run from March to November, with June to August seeing the longest days.

For those in the southern hemisphere, such as Australia, the seasons are reversed: June through August mark winter months and are, therefore, the shortest of the year.

Full moon calendar:When every full moon shines in 2025 in Texas

Is daylight saving time going away?

In recent years, Congress has faced the opportunity to stop changing clocks. In 2022, the U.S. Senate unanimously approved the Sunshine Protection Act, which would make daylight saving time permanent, however the U.S. House of Representatives did not pass it and President Joe Biden did not sign it.

In December, then-President-elect Donald Trump said he aims to put an end to daylight saving time and make standard time year-round.

"The Republican Party will use its best efforts to eliminate Daylight Saving Time, which has a small but strong constituency, but shouldn’t!" Trump wrote on social media site Truth Social. "Daylight Saving Time is inconvenient, and very costly to our Nation."

When does winter end? See first day of spring 2025

Winter officially ends with the first day of spring on Thursday, March 20, 2025.

When is the longest day of the year in 2025? The shortest?

The longest day of 2025, also known as the summer solstice, is Friday, June 20. Central Texas will get around 14 hours of daylight.

On the flip side, 2025's winter solstice — the shortest day of the year — is Sunday, Dec. 21. Austin will see just over 10 hours of daylight.

The Earth is tilted approximately 23.5 degrees on its axis, and each solstice is dictated by the amount of solar declination, or "the latitude of Earth where the sun is directly overhead at noon," according to National Geographic.

body.title: Pebble, the original groundbreaking smartwatch, is coming back
body.description: Pebble founder Eric Migicovsky has revealed he and a small team are working on a new smartwatch to replace the much-loved, ...
body.article_content:
The person behind the Pebble smartwatch, which arguably kickstarted the whole smartwatch craze when it launched in 2012, is returning to build the true successor to it. In a blog post on his personal site, Eric Migicovsky wrote, “A small team and I are diving back into the world of hardware to bring Pebble back!”

His announcement follows Google’s release of the original Pebble smartwatch software — PebbleOS — as open source, allowing keen Pebble owners to more easily adapt it for use with modern smartphones and systems. There is already a healthy fanbase dedicated to keeping Pebble smartwatches and software going, and the open source library will help speed up the process of making old Pebble smartwatches more usable today.

Recommended Videos

Migicovsky continued to explain what his plans are for the new smartwatch:

Please enable Javascript to view this content

“The new watch we’re building basically has the same specs and features as Pebble, though with some fun new stuff as well. It runs open source PebbleOS, and it’s compatible with all Pebble apps and watchfaces. If you had a Pebble and loved it, this is the smartwatch for you.”

Previous Next 1 of 4 Pebble Time Round Digital Trends Pebble Time Malarie Gokey / Digital Trends Pebble Steel Digital Trends Pebble Digital Trends

He also talked about the “core set of features” he wants from a smartwatch, including an always-on, e-paper screen so it can be seen in sunlight and isn’t as power-intensive as an OLED or LCD, buttons on the case, and a simple user interface built on “hackable” software. He specifically mentions wanting to add the ability for developers to build their own watch faces for it. While these features are his wishlist, it’s likely all will make it to his new smartwatch.

Migicovsky calls the project a “Pebble replacement,” but it’s not certain the Pebble name will be used. Pebble was sold to Fitbit, which in turn was purchased by Google, and while the software is now open source, the name may prove more difficult to acquire. Apart from Google possibly owning it, there is another smartwatch company releasing smartwatches using the name Pebble too.

It’s still early days for the project, and Migicovsky wants to complete the product specification and timeline before discussing how you’ll be able to buy one. He ends by saying the new smartwatch will be exactly like the Pebble, “in almost every way,” which is bound to please the many fans of the original. While there will certainly be fans waiting for the new Pebble, smartwatches have moved on since Pebble shook things up between 2012 and 2016. Whether it’s a Casio G-Shock DW-H5600, a Withings ScanWatch 2, or an Apple Watch Series 10, the choice is far wider and more inclusive today.

Since Pebble’s demise, Migicovsky founded Beeper, a universal messaging app which found a way to put iMessage on Android and avoid the whole blue bubble/green bubble social nightmare, without any security problems either. Beeper was acquired by Automattic, which owns WordPress, in 2024.

body.title: OpenAI CEO calls DeepSeek R1 'impressive' and says it's 'invigorating to have a new competitor'
body.description: DeepSeek is making waves with its cost-effective and powerful AI models, with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman praising the Chinese AI ...
body.article_content:
TL;DR: DeepSeek AI, a Chinese startup, has developed cost-effective large-language models using fewer GPUs, rivaling systems from OpenAI, Meta, and Google. This innovation led to a significant drop in NVIDIA's stock. Despite this, NVIDIA praised DeepSeek's advancements. OpenAI's CEO acknowledged DeepSeek's R1 model and hinted at upcoming superior models, emphasizing continued investment in AI development. DeepSeek AI, a Chinese startup, has developed cost-effective large-language models using fewer GPUs, rivaling systems from OpenAI, Meta, and Google. This innovation led to a significant drop in NVIDIA's stock. Despite this, NVIDIA praised DeepSeek's advancements. OpenAI's CEO acknowledged DeepSeek's R1 model and hinted at upcoming superior models, emphasizing continued investment in AI development.

DeepSeek AI is making headlines because the Chinese startup has developed cutting-edge and cost-effective large-language models using fewer GPUs than systems costing billions from companies like OpenAI, Meta, and Google. With the company's flagship R1 model performing on par with OpenAI's o1, this has spilled over to the financial markets, where NVIDIA's stock dipped to the point where it saw the biggest single-day drop in US history.

2

VIEW GALLERY - 2 IMAGES

Despite its market cap dropping by several hundreds of billions, NVIDIA recently released a statement praising DeepSeek as "an excellent AI advancement and a perfect example of Test Time Scaling." DeepSeek's efforts are being widely praised because it didn't require billions of dollars of AI hardware to train.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman released a short statement earlier today on social media on DeepSeek R1, praising it as an "impressive model" while teasing "much better models" coming soon from the company. He also said that OpenAI will bring a few releases forward in response to DeepSeek's surprising and immediate success.

While also teasing AGI.

"DeepSeek's R1 is an impressive model, particularly around what they're able to deliver for the price," Sam Altman wrote on X. "We will obviously deliver much better models, and also, it's legit invigorating to have a new competitor! We will pull up some releases."

"But mostly, we are excited to continue to execute on our research roadmap and believe more compute is more important now than ever before to succeed at our mission," Sam Altman adds, hinting that OpenAI won't be scaling back its use of countless GPUs for its training anytime soon. "The world is going to want to use a lot of AI and really be quite amazed by the next-gen models coming. We look forward to bringing you all AGI and beyond."

Investors routed global high-tech shares to the tune of $1 trillion after buzz from a Chinese startup interrupted the harmony around Silicon Valley’s artificial intelligence. The emergence of DeepSeek, which trained its open-source AI model for a fraction of the costs spent by rivals, prompted investors to reconsider the lofty valuations placed on some European and US technology companies. Nvidia, long a market darling, suffered the largest rout in market history.

Dutch chip-equipment maker ASML fell as much as 12% after money managers considered whether machine-learning algorithms might not consume as much power as previously projected. That realization, in turn, sent shockwaves among electricity-grid suppliers like Siemens Energy and Sweden’s Munters Group. body.title: Lebanon Faces a Colossal Disposal Task: Clearing War Debris
body.description: The conflict between Israel and Hezbollah has left behind lots of rubble. Some experts fear that much of it will be dumped ...
body.article_content:
For the past three months, Ahmad Mehdi has been living in half a home. In October, an Israeli airstrike on the building next to his in a neighborhood south of Beirut blew out most of the kitchen and living room of his fifth-floor apartment.

When he looks at what remains of the building next door, he is overwhelmed by the scale of destruction. “Eleven floors worth of rubble have collapsed into two,” he said. “All you see are rocks and dirt and steel and bits of iron.”

Like many Lebanese whose homes and businesses suffered damage during more than a year of war between Israel and Hezbollah, Mr. Mehdi, 20, and his family are eager to start repairs, but they cannot do much until the rubble is cleared. “That is our biggest problem: Where do we put the debris?” he said.

As Lebanon starts the slow process of rebuilding after a tenuous cease-fire between Hezbollah, the Iran-backed Lebanese militant group, and Israel, it is struggling to figure out how to clean up the vast amounts of rubble left scattered around Beirut, the capital. A report from the National Council for Scientific Research in Lebanon said a preliminary estimate of damages showed that nearly 3,000 buildings in the Dahiya area south of the city had been destroyed, severely damaged or extensively damaged.

body.title: US economic losses from natural disasters soared in 2024, even as they eased globally
body.description: Economic losses from hurricanes and other natural disasters soared in the U.S. last year and were above average globally, reflecting another year of costly severe storms, floods and droughts.
body.article_content:
Economic losses from hurricanes and other natural disasters soared in the U.S. last year and were above average globally, reflecting another year of costly severe storms, floods and droughts.

Damage caused by Hurricanes Helene and Milton helped push total economic losses from natural disasters in the U.S. to $217.8 billion last year, according to insurance broker Aon PLC. That figure represents an 85.3% increase from 2023, when losses totaled about $117.5 billion. It’s also the largest annual tally of economic losses from natural disasters since 2017.

Insured losses, or the portion of economic losses that are covered by insurance, also rose last year. They climbed 36% to $112.7 billion, the most since 2022.

Hurricane Helene tore across six southeastern states last fall, costing $75 billion in economic losses, mainly due to inland and coastal flooding. according to Aon. Less than two weeks later, Hurricane Milton made landfall on the west coast of Florida, causing some $25 billion in economic losses.

body.title: AI-Powered Microservices Architecture Shows Breakthrough Performance in Cloud Computing
body.description: The innovative architectural framework developed by Vaibhav Vudayagiri marks a significant milestone in cloud computing ...
body.article_content:
In this modern era, pioneering innovations from principal architect Vaibhav Vudayagiri reveal a transformative approach to scaling AI systems in cloud environments. His innovative methodology, developed at a leading tech firm, demonstrates remarkable advancements in both performance optimization and operational efficiency.

The Next Generation of Cloud Architecture

The innovative architectural framework revolutionizes AI deployment through advanced microservices patterns, enabling seamless cloud infrastructure scaling. By breaking down complex AI systems into modular, independently scalable components, organizations achieve remarkable efficiency gains. The framework's near-linear scalability and 45% cost reduction demonstrate its superiority over monolithic architectures that often bottleneck under expanding AI workloads.

Breaking Down the Innovation

The modular AI architecture divides complex systems into standalone components, each handling specific tasks like vision or language processing. This separation enables teams to independently optimize and scale individual modules. Organizations report dramatic improvements: 40% better system performance and 75% faster development cycles through parallel workstreams and targeted enhancements of each component.

Revolutionizing Resource Management

One of the most significant breakthroughs is in resource utilization. The new architecture demonstrates a 30% improvement in resource efficiency, with CPU utilization increasing from 40% to 70% on average. This enhanced efficiency translates to substantial cost savings and reduced environmental impact, with energy efficiency improving by 25%.

Real-Time Processing Breakthrough

The system has achieved remarkable improvements in real-time processing capabilities. The architecture can handle a tenfold increase in request volume with only a minimal 20% increase in response time. This breakthrough enables AI applications to process millions of operations per second while maintaining consistent performance, a crucial capability for modern AI-driven services.

Security and Compliance Evolution

The framework incorporates advanced security measures that have shown impressive results. Implementation of modern authentication methods has reduced unauthorized access attempts by 60%, while new encryption protocols have virtually eliminated successful data breaches. These security improvements don't come at the cost of performance – the system maintains high availability with 99.99% uptime.

Transforming User Experience

The optimized architecture has transformed user interactions. With AI operations now executing 40% faster at 300ms versus the previous 500ms, users experience notably smoother interactions. The 15% boost in AI accuracy further elevates the experience, resulting in measurably higher satisfaction scores and more efficient task completion.

Future-Ready Innovation

The framework's dynamic adaptability revolutionizes cloud computing by intelligently responding to fluctuating workloads. Its sophisticated architecture seamlessly scales resources in real-time, effortlessly absorbing traffic surges while preventing resource waste during lulls. This precise elasticity optimizes cost efficiency and delivers unwavering performance, marking a breakthrough in cloud infrastructure management and operational excellence.

Business Impact and Efficiency

Organizations implementing this architecture have seen transformative results. Development velocity increased dramatically, with new feature deployment accelerated by 60% - shrinking timelines from months to weeks. Beyond the technical advantages, businesses achieved measurable gains in user engagement, with AI-enhanced features driving a significant 23% boost in conversion rates, delivering tangible bottom-line impact.

Sustainable Computing

The enhanced architectural design revolutionizes sustainable computing through intelligent resource management. By dynamically allocating computational resources and implementing advanced power-saving algorithms, the system achieves remarkable energy efficiency without compromising processing capabilities. The optimization reduces electricity consumption and cooling requirements, directly lowering carbon emissions. This innovation proves that cutting-edge performance can coexist with environmental stewardship, setting a new standard for eco-conscious computing solutions.

In conclusion, the innovative architectural framework developed by Vaibhav Vudayagiri marks a significant milestone in cloud computing advancement. His approach not only revolutionizes AI system scaling but also establishes a robust foundation for future cloud solutions. This breakthrough enables organizations to build more efficient and sustainable AI-driven systems, optimizing both operational costs and environmental impact while paving the way for next-generation computing capabilities.

body.title: What to Expect When Starting Out With Microsegmentation
body.description: If you’re building a zero trust architecture, microsegmentation should be a crucial part of your plan. Here are the 10 things ...
body.article_content:
Originally published by Illumio.

Written by Christer Swartz, Solutions Marketing Director, Illumio.





According to Gartner, “By 2026, 60% of enterprises working toward zero trust architecture will use more than one deployment form of microsegmentation, which is up from less than 5% in 2023.”

Microsegmentation is foundational to zero trust. You can’t achieve zero trust without it.

In fact, John Kindervag, the creator of Zero Trust, addressed the connection between zero trust and segmentation in the second report ever written on the topic, Build Security Into Your Network’s DNA: The Zero Trust Network Architecture. In the report, he said, “New ways of segmenting networks must be created because all future networks need to be segmented by default.”

If you’re building a zero trust architecture, microsegmentation should be a crucial part of your plan. Here are the 10 things you can expect to do when starting out with microsegmentation.‍





1. Get visibility into all workload traffic across every environment

The first — and one of the most important — steps of building microsegmentation is being able to know what’s going on across all segments in your network. How do you see all traffic between all workloads across your cloud, endpoint, and data center environments? It’s crucial to be able to achieve this level of visibility at any scale without an overly complex workflow.

You can try to use different visibility tools for different segments across your network. But using multiple tools will create a fragmented view. This can make it challenging to understand behavior across all segments everywhere.

Instead, find a solution that can discover traffic across all segments and display it in one view.





‍2. Understand how apps are communicating

Most people agree that Zero Trust is a good idea, but how can you understand what traffic is required before deciding what to protect? It’s not always easy to see what apps are running across your network and what ports they need to use.

With the right solution, you can discover what applications are running on all workloads and what ports they’re using. This provides a comprehensive inventory of all applications and their dependencies in your network so you can decide how to enforce segmentation policy.

‍

3. Lock down your most critical, highest-risk resources

Not all entry points into your network are under your direct control. While a data center for a campus network might have strong controls in place, resources in the cloud or partners’ third-party access are often less secure.

Many threats start from these less-secure environments because they’re often left open due to human error. Any of these access points can be an attacker’s first step in the door, allowing threats to move across your network to your high-value assets.





The dotted lines represent open ports between environments which allow malware to spread through the network.

That’s where a microsegmentation solution can help you secure these vulnerable parts of your network. No matter where a breach happens, microsegmentation will block it from reaching critical resources that you’ve segmented. The breach will be isolated to the other side of that segment so it can’t cause further damage. ‍





4. Label workloads by business functions, not network addresses

In today’s modern networks, workloads are deployed across a hybrid, multi-cloud architecture. This makes network addresses ephemeral. A workload’s network address can change dynamically depending on the underlying hosting environment.

That’s why you should label workloads using human-readable labels rather than traditional IP addresses. With a microsegmentation solution, you can identify workloads by their business function or ownership — such as their role, application, environment, location, operating system, or business unit — which is a lot more informative their using an IP address.

By using human-readable labels, you get a metadata-driven solution for seeing how segments between workloads are enforced that is fully decoupled from network address. ‍





5. Decide on an agent and agentless approach

When building microsegmentation, it's important to understand when an agent or agentless approach works best. Some solutions give you a choice between using agents or not so that you can get visibility and segmentation across all workloads in every environment.

Agent approach

Collects telemetry about application use on and between workloads. This allows you to control access to segments directly at the workload.

Agentless approach

Discovers and enforces the use of segments without an agent.

This is crucial in environments that can’t support agents, like IoT devices in the manufacturing or healthcare industries. It’s also key in environments that can’t use agents because of compliance requirements.





‍6. Start with a denylist model, then move to an allowlist model

A common challenge teams run into when building microsegmentation is that they know the ports they want to deny, but they don’t fully understand all the ports they need to allow for applications.

Ransomware commonly uses ports such as Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) and Server Message Block (SMB) to move across segments between workloads. But we know that these ports rarely need to be open between workloads.

That’s why it’s best practice to start with a denylist model. Block only the ports you know shouldn’t be open and allow all others. Then, when you have a full understanding of what ports applications need, you can switch to an allowlist model. Keep only the required ports open and block all others.

This approach allows you to begin building microsegmentation by ransomware today and tightening policy when you’re ready.

‍

7. Model policy before it’s deployed

Cybersecurity has long relied on a deploy-and-pray approach. Security teams create a policy model and modify it until it looks correct. Then, when it’s deployed, they pray the phone doesn’t ring from broken application dependencies.

That’s why it’s best to test your policy before it's fully deployed. Modeling ensures your policy can be deployed safely without the risk of inadvertently breaking application dependencies.





8. Extend consistent segmentation across the hybrid multi-cloud

If you use a solution that can only build segmentation in the data center, then you’re unlikely to get consistent security in other environments like the cloud. Segmentation should never be dependent on a single environment. This will result in a siloed approach to segmentation which will only leave vulnerabilities and make it harder to stop and contain breaches.

Instead, microsegmentation needs to follow the workload as it migrates across environments. This ensures that segmentation doesn’t break as workloads are hosting in different environments.





‍9. Automate security changes without relying on human decisions

Malware spreads faster than any human can type on a keyboard. It’s crucial to have a microsegmentation solution that can automate policy changes as fast as a breach can spread.

‍

10. Prove security is in compliance

Quantifying risk can be challenging, since securing applications and segments can involve many moving parts. During an audit, it’s not always easy to get a clear picture of existing risk and how it’s lowered after security policy is applied. It’s important to use tools that show this before and after comparison.





About the Author

Christer Swartz is Solutions Marketing Director at Illumio. He has spent many years in the Networking industry, beginning with a small startup called Cisco. He was previously with Netflix, designing the birth of their Internet video-streaming architecture, and also with Palo Alto Networks, designing deep security in both data center and cloud architectures.

body.title: Archaeologists uncover major new find studying China’s mysterious 2,000 year old Terracotta Army
body.description: Dating back thousands of years, the Terracotta Army guards the mausoleum of Qin Shi Huang and has never been opened.
body.article_content:
A 2,000-year-old tomb guarded by thousands of terracotta soldiers continues to surprise archaeologists after a new major find was discovered at the site in rural China.

Known as the Terracotta Army, it is one of the most famous discoveries in humanity's history.

With 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots and 520 horses, the sculptures - made purely out of terracotta - were only found in 1974. Guarding the tomb of China's very first emperor, Qin Shi Huang, they had stood in place since the late 200s BC; making them more than 2,200 years old.

Advert

Qin Shi Huang is one of the most influential people in China's history as the first leader to unite the country after centuries of regional conflict.

Finds in one of the pits at the tomb (China Photos/Getty Images)

New finding at the Terracotta Army

Despite being found back in 1974, work continues on the site with new finds discovered over the years since.

Advert

And now, according to the head of the excavation project, Zhu Sihong, a first-of-its-kind find has been located in the area.

An area known as Pit 1 is where the biggest find to date has been located, with 3,000 figures in an area 230 metres long and 62 metres wide.

But it is in Pit 2 - home to war chariots and cavalry - where the newfound has been located.

Here a brand new figure has been located.

Advert

Zhu, speaking to China's state broadcaster CCTV, said: "Based on its location, we believe this figure was likely the highest-ranking military commander of this unit."

Terracotta horses were also uncovered (Tim Graham/Getty Images)

Why is it important?

The find is a life-size - and decorated - figure believed to be that of a senior military official.

Advert

Now, the hope is that it could be a huge point in understanding the Qin dynasty, which only ruled from 221BC to 207BC.

According to CCTV, the armour is adorned with detailed patterns, ribbons, and floral knots.

It is only the tenth of its kind ever to be found in the tomb home to more than 8,000 statues and a size of more than 20 square miles.

“These adornments on the high-ranking officers indicate how special they are,” Xiuzhen Janice Li, an archaeologist at the University of Oxford, told Live Science.

Advert

Li, who worked at Emperor Qin Shi Huang’s Mausoleum Site Museum, added: "The style and colour of the adornments featured the aesthetic taste and social status symbols of the time.

"The arrangement of the high-ranking officers in the military formation reflected the military strategy, such as [the] commanding system in the Qin dynasty."

The uncovered army (Getty Stock Image)

The tomb

Found back in 1974, the Terracotta Army and the tomb of Qin Shi Huang were discovered by accident.

This was after local farmer Yang Zhifa came across fragments of pottery when digging for a well.

Once uncovered, the tomb came as a genuine surprise with no historical documentation of it ever existing. The entire thing had sat untouched, and unknown, for 2,200 years.

While the sculptures mostly look like the terracotta they are made of, they were actually painted at the time to represent the people they portrayed.

Traces still exist but most of the paint didn't last the time, with reports that some of the painted surfaces started to flake and fade as soon as they were excavated.

As for the tomb of Qin Shi Huang - which is sealed airtight - it remains unopened to this day due to issues regarding preserving what is on the inside. There is also a fear of the tomb being boobytrapped due keep grave robbers out.

As of now, all archaeological proposals have been rejected by China.
